b: ^Another morning.  Another start of the week.
^For many the most hated day.  A day to dread the slog to the office, to fear the work to be done, to hope for the end.
^But this is foolish.  Monday is an opportunity.  A day where you can show your worth to the world.  Worth that comes    from the quality, and capability, of your actions.
^How can one not delight in a Monday, when all other days have less of the working week to look forward to.
^For to be perfect is such bliss,
^Upon this day fools love to loathe.
^Yes... I think today will be a good day.
^ is hitting their deadlines I've got nothing to worry about.
^And a good day deserves to be followed by a good meal.
^This fridge is getting a little empty, I'll have to go shopping soon.
^That's fine, I have the time. I can just go later in the week.
^[Charlie rises miffed but optimistic about his ability to sort things.]
^[Reasons that only having approximately one day for each week
^ spent on it probably equates their different productivity levels well.]
^[Day was slower than desired due to
^[Also, this meal is the last dinner food in the house.  Further meals will require the time to shop.]
^[Charlie hopes for a lucky break today, so that he might have time to restock his food supplies.]
^[Charlie returns with fast food having been very unlucky.]
^ were missing and it hampered progress so much he'd done half a day of overtime to make up for it.]
^[Tiredness is starting to seep in after these few unusual days.]
^[Today was even harder than yesterday, putting his arrival slightly after midnight.]
^[Dinner food was used up on Tuesday. The only resort is to eat breakfast supplies instead.]
^ is so wiped he can barely eat without sleeping.]
^I had the last breakfast food last night.
^I haven't known you very long, but I hope our time together lasts.
^: Hey good lookin'. I noticed you were good looking.
^I can still see you.  So... maybe...
^I could try relaxing like you do.

b: ^A functional object at a functional size.
^If I can make something of myself; why can't you make yourself too
^: Hey man, I was looking for you at the end of work, didn't manage to find you.
^: Well, y'see, apparently my work on the account wasn't

^: And it all needs to be redone so it has to be started from scratch and the deadline is Friday and its going to be so much work and also the boss said I can't be trusted so it's your responsibility now.
^: You are aware I am the best in the department and already have a full schedule of work.
^: Yeah, yeah, I know but... Boss man's orders...
^: Fine. Just make sure you get me everything I need by the time I sit down after the morning meeting.
^: If you can stretch to that.
^: Haha, yeah sure thing.  No worries.
^Well, that is going to be inconvenient.
^As long as I can give full attention to my work over the coming days I have no reason to worry though.
^I'll get it all done, and I'll do it all myself.
^It's pretty clear no one else is capable of helping me with anything.
^I could do everything much better on my own.
^ mentally rallies around the idea that he can push himself harder tomorrow and fix everything.]

^: Just a little more and you'll be through this.
^An excellent way to get to work on time.
^Taking the car has a much higher chance of getting stuck in traffic, as they cannot use the bus lanes.  Therefore resulting in a late arrival.
^That is to say nothing of how late walking would make me.
^This journey is at least an hour on foot.
^Indeed, the bus suits me just fine.
^[Charlie finds himself unable to get change for a large bank note from the bus driver.]
^[An unknown passenger saves him from the dilemma of massively over paying, or walking, by exchanging him several less significant notes.]
^[Eager to get started on things, Charlie impatiently rides the bus to work.]
^[Disappointed in the twists his day took Charlie considers the fast food place as they drive past.]
^[Thinking he might need to buy meals if his days continue their current productivity trajectory.]
^[Charlie barely notices the journey, as he's already solving work problems in his head.]
^ travels home well past dinner time, yet departs the bus at an earlier stop.]
^'s stop is next to the fast food place where he will buy dinner before carrying it home.]
^ boards the bus tired.  He is crabby with the people he talks to.]
^ gets to work he is unsure if he slept on the bus, or just sat there unthinking the whole time.]
^[An even later return than Wednesday.  It's practically midnight.]
^ makes the same early exit at the fast food restaurant.]
^[Charlie tries to take his car instead, but finds no one operating the barrier in his car park.]
^[Charlie walks to work, hoping to find another bus service, or taxi to hail, on his way.]
^[He finds neither and walks the whole 70 minutes to the office as it begins to rain.]
^Quick stop in the cubicle to deposit my things, then it's off to the morning meeting.
^As expected, everyone is looking most dreary today.
^ looking that chipper - especially on a Monday morning.
^I guess he's finally going to be done with that big account of his.
^The completion of quality work: truly a marvelous feeling.
^Regardless, I'm sure he'll stop by to waste my time, now that his is suddenly so free.
^To lunch I go; I must confess.
^How did you manage to say that to him again.
^What?  Maybe once every second weekend after a blue moon.  Is that a good enough baseline?
^How embarassing.  I wish no one would ever see me a-
^: Hey there! Is that another Gardenflower coffee I see in your hand?
^: You know that place is like- 15 minutes away right?  We have a coffee shop on the ground floor.
^: What are you talking about it's just a pen?
^: And what about the other hand?
^: Yes that would be a, um, what did you call it? "Wallflower"... coffee...?
^: So, big news!  I've finished that big account I was working on.  Can you believe it's finally over after almost a month!
^: Yes, I spotted you being uncharacteristicly happy before 5pm.  I knew something was up.
^: Oh not yet.  It's only just finished!
^: Jeez!  I can take a little time to breathe before bringing it to the boss.
^: Of course you do.  But does it have to be my time you take?
^: It's not my lunch break anymore you know.
^ is not in the morning meeting.  Charlie gets on with other work expecting
^ still isn't around and by mid afternoon

^ works as best he can but finds that certain people are slow to respond to his emails]
^ will not be getting those particular email requests answered.]
^ puts in additional hours (roughly 3 more) to catch up time lost to finding his own answers.]
^[Morning meeting must've been staffed with roughly one third the ususal staff.]
^ already knows this is not good news for making up lost work today, but resolves to make the best of it.]
^[After a very low productivity day due to the office skeleton crew
^A lovely experience in an otherwise dull part of the day.
^Much better than quietly sitting in the office, legally obligated not to continue working.
^Their selection of handmade sandwhiches makes the perfect union with that barista's finely brewed coffee.
^: Good afternoon.  What can I get you?
^: You've reached the front of the line...
^: Occasionally people like to use such an opportunity to tell me their order.
^: Wow, you sure look like you're with the angels today.
^: You think I look like an angel?
^: Well, I mean- I er- work out... And I- um- try to eat healthy-
^: Oh, um, I- It's not that you-
^: You looked like your head was in the clouds, is all I intended.
^: Perhaps you'd like your usual order? I can sort your latte just now and deliver your food when it's finished heating.
^: Yes please that sounds good thank you very much.
^I should hear what he has to say...
^: ...would you like me to make you a to-go latte when you leave today too?
^: If you're looking for the ambrosia, then I'm afraid we don't have any.
^: I've heard regular humans suffer for eating it, and I can't risk poisoning all my customers.
^: I but seach for the fare of mortals.
^: But if you did come across any ambrosia...
^: I'm sure you, at least, could share that meal with me.
^: Well, I don't know if you noticed but there's no one here right now-
^: -and I've been eyeing these brownies for what feels like hours now...
^: So how about we share that meal now?
^: After I get you what you want, that is.
^I should restrict my answer to lunch related options.
^: He really did that? And the deadline is in three days?!
^: Oh, absolutely.  But it's no issue.  I can get it done one way or the other.
^: Tackling challenges by myself has never been a barrier to my success before.
^: That's a lot to take on...
^: You must live for the weekends.  There's nothing like having a lazy day when you've earned it.
^I usually spend weekends planning other work, or itching for Monday...
^: Haha, yeah.  I love to relax.  I know exactly what that entails.
^: That's good!  It was starting to sound like your time was all spent working.
^: It's nice to hear you might have some to spare.
^: Oh- But look, I have a customer.  And you are overdue a to-go latte if I've got the time right.
^: It'll be available to pick up whenever you're ready to collect it.
^[The barista is not in the shop.  His job having been replaced by a succession of vending machines dispensing hot drinks, cold drinks, and packaged sandwiches.]
^[Charlie returns to the Gardenflower, not knowing how else to spend his lunch.]
^ isn't there, perhaps there'll be something to tell him where he is.]
^[He does not enjoy his electronically vended meal.  If he wanted calories, he could've stayed at the office.]
^[Charlie is terse and unkind to the fast food worker.]
^[Charlie thinks about how insignificant their job is, and the idea that what little money they earn is probably too much.]
^[Perhaps has a sad thought about the higher quality workers (the barista) that he can't buy from anymore.]
^[Charlie arrives after an exhausting day just needing anything for dinner that night.]
^[The fast food restaurant is closed.  A note inside the door citing a lack of staff.]
^: Please. You can't not be here!
^: What am I supposed to eat!
